Congratulations to MHS hockey sensation, Hunter Miller, for being honored with this year's Hobey Baker award.

In 2003, the Hobey Baker High School Character Award was established to honor high school hockey players who exemplify the Hobey Baker ideal that "Character Builds Excellence." Candidates for a High School Hobey Baker Award are selected based on the following criteria:

Coachability
Strength of character
Integrity
Commitment
Teamwork
Community leadership
Outstanding sportsmanship.

Each year, a single senior hockey player from each participating high school is selected to be honored by teammates and celebrated by the school and the community for outstanding individual performance on and off the ice.

Congratulations to Marysville High School, Marysville Middle School, Morton Elementary School, and Gardens Elementary School for being designated as "REWARD" schools by the Michigan Department of Education's A-F Grading System. Reward schools are those schools identified as being high achieving public schools. These schools are identified annually. Any school not identified as a low-performing school and meeting the following criteria are identified as Reward Schools. Schools that have earned a letter grade of ‚ÄúA‚Äù in any of the following indicators:

- Student Proficiency
- Student Growth
- Performance Among Peers or high schools with four-year graduation rates of at least 99%

Note: schools cannot be identified as "REWARD" if they have underperforming subgroups

For more information about the state's A-F Grading System, please see "2018‚Äì19 Michigan School Grades Parent Guide" at https://bit.ly/343NiH5 or visit Mi School Data at https://bit.ly/2wPq2jS.

This is important not just to prevent the spread of COVID-19, but to help prevent the spread of other infections that can lead to student illness and absences.

This past weekend, Marysville Middle School hosted the FIRST Lego League Marysville Qualifier. Twenty-two robotics teams participated in this very successful event!

The competition consisted of 4 areas of judging: Knowledge and Implementation of the programs Core Values, Robot Design, the Innovation Research project, and the Robot Competition Field.

Two teams from Morton Elementary, the Mini Vi-Bots, and the Micro Vi-Bots, had a very productive and rewarding day. Both teams completed the competition in good standings. The Mini Vi-Bots received the Research Award for their Innovation Project presentation of installing Street Lights on the on/off ramps of I-94 at the Marysville Exit. This also provided the team an invitation to compete at the FIRST Lego League State Competitions in West Bloomfield on December 14th!

Congrats to both Morton Robotics Teams on your accomplishments at this year's Marysville Competition!
